comment.author: 22948027@N02
comment._content: Text in Norwegian, first picture: 'Bestyrerboligen i Husvik Harbour' - The manager's house in Husvik Harbour. The three other pictures are of whale catch ships, which brought the whales into the factory for 'processing', i.e. boiling the blubber to extract the whale oil. Just the same way as a steam ship's name was proceeded by a "S.S.", these whalecathers that in the early 20th century was spelled "hvalbaat" in Norwegian, have a "HB" before their actual name. Floating factories ("Flytende kokerier") was marked Fl/k, or F/K. HB Knöl, the second ship, is named after the shortened name for humpback whale in Norwegian: Knölhval.

comment.author: 22948027@N02
comment._content: The photographer´s name, Hans Torgersen, is written on the negative of the latter two pictures.

comment.author: 22948027@N02
comment._content: The Husvik Harbour whaling station is deserted since many decades, but some buildings including the manager's house still stands, and it seems to be well looked after. See this picture on Panoramico: www.panoramio.com/photo/9230865?source=wapi&referrer=...
